Constructor Detail

Command

public Command(T handler,
               java.lang.String command,
               java.lang.String help,
               int minParams,
               int maxParams)
Command constructor method.

Parameters:
handler - Your command handler.
command - The command in string form (e.g. "/test").
help - Usage or any other help message (e.g. "Prints a test message").
minParams - The minimum number of parameters one is allowed to send.
maxParams - The maximum number of parameters one is allowed to send (-1 for infinity).

containsHTML

public boolean containsHTML()
Whether or not the message contains HTML. Use this when you're printing your command messages in an HTML compatible text area.

Returns:
True if the message contains HTML, else false.

getAllHelp

public static java.lang.String getAllHelp(boolean HTML)
Will return a String with all the commands and their help/usage messages.

Parameters:
HTML - True you want it formatted in HTML, false if not.
Returns:
A String with all the command and their help/usage messages. If no commands are in the list "No commands" will be returned.

stringParams

public static java.lang.String stringParams(java.lang.String[] params,
                                            int start)
This method will take your parameters String array and combine all the indexes into one String object.

Parameters:
params - The String array of parameters.
start - The index with which you'd like to start combining.
Returns:
A String object which contains all the parameters combined.

parseCommand

public static java.lang.String parseCommand(java.lang.String command)
Will parse a command from an input String. For example: "/test param1 param2" will return "/test".

Parameters:
command - The input to parse.
Returns:
The parsed command.

parseParams

public static java.lang.String[] parseParams(java.lang.String command)
Will parse the parameters from an input String into a String array. For example: "/test param1 param2" will return {"param1", "param2}.

Parameters:
command - The input to parse.
Returns:
The parsed parameters.

getCommand

public static Command<?> getCommand(java.lang.String command)
Possibly the most important method. Use this method to get a command object using String from the command list.

Parameters:
command - The command you'd like to get (e.g. "/test")
Returns:
The command object corresponding to the provided String. Null if not found.

public java.lang.String toString()
Overrides:

checkAndExecute

public void checkAndExecute(java.lang.String[] params)
This method will check the validity of the parameters and execute it if the check is successful.

Parameters:
params - A String array of the parameters you'd like to execute this command with.

check

public boolean check(T handler,
                     java.lang.String[] params)
The method that checks the validity of a parameters String array for this command. You should never really have to explicitly call this method. Use checkAndExecute(String[]) instead.

The default check method simply checks if the length of the String array of parameters falls within the bounds of the minParams and maxParams of this command. You could override it with your own class if it's creating issues.

Parameters:
handler - The command handler you're working with.
params - A String array of parameters.
Returns:
True if the check is successful, else false.

tooManyParameters

public void tooManyParameters(T handler,
                              java.lang.String[] params)
This method gets called if the check method finds that the parameter array provided contains too many parameters. The idea is that you can override this method to write your own code for these situations.

Parameters:
handler - The command handler you're working with.
params - A String array of parameters.

missingParameters

public void missingParameters(T handler,
                              java.lang.String[] params)
This method gets called if the check method finds that the parameter array provided contains too little parameters. The idea is that you can override this method to write your own code for these situations.

Parameters:
handler - The command handler you're working with.
params - A String array of parameters.

execute

public abstract void execute(T handler,
                             java.lang.String[] params)
The execute code. You should never really have to explicitly call this method. Use checkAndExecute(String[]) instead.

Simply put whatever code you'd like to be run in here, and when this command is executed the code will be run.

Parameters:
handler - The command handler you're working with.
params - A String array of parameters.
